column1: What does RUNNABLE mean in Java?
column2: A thread is either running on CPU or ready to run. It does NOT guarantee actual execution.

column1: Which thread type prevents JVM shutdown?
column2: A non-daemon (worker) thread keeps the JVM alive.
It blocks the calling thread until the target thread finishes execution.

column1: Why is extending Thread usually discouraged?
column2: Because it prevents inheritance and mixes task logic with execution.
Both the JVM and the operating system.

column1: Does thread start order guarantee execution order?
column2: No. Execution order is controlled by the OS scheduler.

column1: What happens if only daemon threads remain?
What is the main responsibility of Runnable?
column2: To represent a unit of work without controlling execution.

column1: Is RUNNABLE the same as running?
column2: No. RUNNABLE includes both running and ready-to-run states.
